headline: Flan II
description: Caramelized sugar, milk and eggs -- a sweet and simple baked custard.
name: Flan II

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
In a heavy bottomed saucepan over medium heat, melt 1/2 cup sugar until golden. Carefully pour hot sugar evenly into four oven-proof ramekins or custard cups, tilting cups to coat bottoms evenly.

In another saucepan, bring milk just to boiling over medium heat. Stir hot milk, a little at a time, into beaten eggs and egg yolks, until well combined. Stir in sugar. Pour milk mixture evenly into ramekins.

Line a roasting pan with a damp kitchen towel. Place ramekins on towel, inside roasting pan, and place roasting pan on oven rack. Fill roasting pan with boiling water to reach halfway up the sides of the ramekins.
Bake in preheated oven 40 minutes, until set. Let cool, invert and serve.

review.reviewBody: This is a beautiful flan with a great texture - smooth and creamy, but firm enough to cut with a spoon. I added a tsp of good quality vanilla, but it wasn't necessary, if you prefer the sweet eggy flavor. For ease of preparation, I heated the milk in the sauce pan with the caramel residue, which dissolves the caramelized sugar into the milk, adding to the custard's flavor. This recipe is a keeper. By the way, if you're going to bake the cups in an aluminum pan, you should sprinkle a little cream of tartar into the water (NOT the flan) to keep the inside of the pan from oxidizing (turning dark). I adjusted this recipe for 6 to fill 8 small ramekins, but I left the caramel at 1/2 cup sugar.
Neat and simple recipe! Made a couple of batches one with the recipe here and the other with some vanilla extract. Both came out great!

Anything can be good if you put love into it. This is the best recipe by far. I did my own little tweaks for it but it's still good! I replace one cup of the whole milk with heavy whipping cream for that extra smooth taste...
Made a mistake and didn’t use boiling water!! Just waited it out as it was still liquid at 40 min and ended up baking it 30 min longer. It still came out great!
I'm not done making mine yet but i just would like to put a fair warning that it takes longer then 40 min in the oven (in mine at least)

I had never made flan before and was a bit intimidated. I looked at a few recipes and most of them called for sweetened condensed milk and evaporated milk. I have nothing against these ingredients, I just don't generally keep them in my pantry. This recipe was simple with well written directions I had no troubles following and the flan was perfection. I will definitely be making this one again.

I have made several flans and this was not good, IMO, my children didn't like it either and they LOVE flan. The texture was wrong and the flavor was off. Like another reviewer said, it tasted like egg; it tasted like watery eggs and milk to me, blah. If you thought this was good, don't settle, keep trying other recipes because there are some you might like even better out there. What I don't understand is people giving a recipe 4 or 5 stars and then adding and changing a multitude of items to the point that it's not the original recipe.
Tried this recipe and ended up with a watery mess. Not traditional and no clear instructions on how to add eggs. Ended up with scrambled eggs in milky mess.
This turned out as a curdled mess, and the milk mixture completely absorbed the caramel.
I subbed sugar with monk fruit sweetener. Came out great!!
My wife absolutely love it. She stated that it wasn’t too sweet as the one with condensed milk.
This was an easy recipe and my husband loved it. I did add 1/2 tsp of vanilla.
I love the simplicity of the ingredients, and loved substituting New Hampshire maple syrup for the melted sugar to give it a little New England flair.
This recipe reminds me of the flan my family made when I was a girl. It was perfectly, delicately sweet. The texture is silky smooth. I did add a teaspoon of vanilla because I love the flavor.
Recipe was easy to follow, I added a tablespoon of vanilla. The flan is silky and smooth.

I had never before made a custard or any dessert like this before. The directions were easy to follow and it turned out beautifully and was so good to eat. Thank you do much for sharing your delicious recipe!
Flan is just not me if it has that eggy taste.
I made this for my mom, she loved it!
Can't seem to get the Carmel right but I like it without the extra sugar. the recipe worked to make chocoflan :)

The only change I made was adding a splash of vanilla. I added it only because my partner ALWAYS wants vanilla in desserts.
The one worry I had was when, after melting the sugar and pouring it into the little dishes, it immediately hardened. I couldn't let it run to cover the bottom. I soldiered on and followed the instructions. It turned out fine. The sugar returned to liquid and my partner declared it a winner!
I will make it again as there are so few ingredients, it's easy to make and it is a winner
It's almost impossible to get this recipe wrong ... I love it!!!
This was an easy, fun recipe to make. Very classic taste, everyone really liked it.

This flan recipe is better than any I have tried, because it wasn't too sweet, and you don't have to make a special sauce for it.
I have made it about 5 times now, and I hope to make it a lot more in the future. Love it!!!

This was one of the easiest recipes to follow. I am more than glad to have this recipe by my side that really came out to the best final touches. I would recommend this to anyone who just has eggs and 2 percent milk, and no evaporated and condensed milk. There was an altercation to my recipe that I had prepared with this one, which was that I added Chocolate Caramel coffee creamer to my milk, and added cocoa powder with the sugar that was for the caramelized topping. This is just a generic flan recipe, but it was the basic one. If you want to make a different kind of flan, like the Mexican-style custard, or even a cream cheese flan, this really wouldn't be the recipe to go ahead and start on. Also, be ready to make sure your flan is cooked right, in order to be able to set it on the platter correctly. If you use PAM spray all over and coat with it on your metal or glass pan, the flan comes right out in perfection. Really glad I found this recipe, did not let me down and I would do it again.

Caramel burns! I have the blister to prove it. That being said, it is a new favorite recipe for my family and I will be more careful next time.
I made this the first time for a party of 20, in multiple batches. Burned myself in first batch. Second batch was much easier to deal with because I knew what to expect. When working with the caramel, pour small amount into the ramekins, then swirl to cover sides when done pouring. It is a little more forgiving than you would think. OR>>> instead of the caramel, sprinkle brown sugar to cover the bottom of the ramekins. You can turn it out and use the torch to caramelize or leave as is and eat from the ramekin.

Amazing recipe. Mine turned out great. And to be extra fancy I melted some additional sugar at the end and poured it on the baking mat into various shapes to stick them in the finished desserts. Everyone was in awe

If what you are expecting is the heavy solid flan typically served in america this isn't it. This is very light, delicate and dissolves in your mouth. OK if it's what you wanted. None of my group cared for it.

This was my first time making Flan . . . and it turned out pretty good! I think I did make a slight error in that while I was melting the sugar, I think I let it cook a little too long. I had stirred the sugar, which created sugar clumps, and in order to get the clumps to dissolve, I had to cook it a little longer. I wonder if you're not supposed to stir it?? Anyways, it still turned out fantastic! The only adjustments I made was to use half & half, as I had exactly 2 cups that needed to be used up, and I added a tad bit of vanilla. This makes a beautiful presentation on a plate with fresh berries on the side. Thanks for the recipe!

Really good. Picture I posted didn’t do it justice. I couldn’t wait till it cooled to eat. Left one in the fridge overnight and it turned out looking like restaurant quality. Best tasting Flan I’ve ever eaten. Best of you let it cool properly, but I’m weak, so there...

I made this with 1/2 cup Swerve sweetener instead of using sugar for the keto diet. Turned out nice and better than other recipes I've used. Nice it doesn't require sweetened condensed milk. Didn't do any sugar glaze/syrup as I just wanted the custard part. Will be making this again.
This is my go to flan recipe every year for Christmas dinner! It's SOOO good!
The best flan, without the calories. Can be made in one dish. On top of stove in a double boiler or baked. Optional, top with Cool Whip or cream. Good breakfast dish with some fruit.

I honestly loved this recipe. The taste was so close to an Asian flan which obviously, fit my tastebud completely due to my craving of an Asian flan taste when I came to America. I did add about a small spoon of vanilla extract and a bit of condense milk just to make it more flavorable. I also added one more egg just so it can be more dense. although I had some trouble with the caramel base, after I baked the flan, 1/3 of my caramel was still hard. Any suggestions for the caramel to melt easier?
This was delectable. Simple and tender with a light texture and perfect balance of sweetness from the caramel. I didn't change a thing. A perfect ending to a family recipe of enchiladas.
Let's start with what I liked about the flan...not to sweet.

This is a good basic recipe. Flan is an egg custard dessert and this recipe is using the simplest basic ingredient to make custard. The texture is just good. The only thing I would add for this recipe (for people used to eat commercial made flans!) is putting some vanilla extract or seasonings like cinnamon in caramel. The pure egg custard flan is perfect for children and people who trying to eat healthy(by simple ingredients) with no additional heavy cream in the ingredients list. Also, next time I make it for kids, I would omit caramel part for them??
It's so FLANTASTIC!!!!!!!
This flan is a divine food

This was so simple to make! This was my first time making flan and I followed the recipe pretty much exactly - the only change I made was that I used 1/2 cup cream for 1/2 cup of the milk (I had some cream I wanted to use up). I wondered about putting the damp cloth in the bottom of the pan - I guess it has something to do with regulating the temperature around the custard cups? anyhow, I did as the recipe said and it worked out perfectly. The flan was delicious and a real treat!
Added vanilla and did not add the extra sugar to the yolk. Was great!
i am confused by what happened to the caramelized sugar. it became like glass. remembering last time i had flan, the sugar was not like glass.
I made this flan in one big pan instead of smaller individual ones. The flavor was great but the texture was too much like eggs. Maybe it will work better in a flan pan?

Simplest most delicate, decadent Milk Flan/Custard on the planet. Of note, please do NOT stir sugar that will coat your ramekin(s) and don't over darken. To add "flavor" to your Flan, use "light" flavors, remember this is a very light dessert. Use a little vanilla, almond, orange, anise or other type flavoring. I use the skin of a Lime after incorporating the sugar when "scalding" the milk. I also completely chill the milk prior to adding the 4 "whole" eggs. Never failed me yet. Good Luck.

Although I haven't made this exact recipe, I have a recipe that is almost identical to this that was given to me by a vietnamese lady except everything is upped to make 13-14 servings and with the addition of rum and vanilla extract. I will say that I prefer the recipe with whole milk (like this) instead of condensed milk. It's much less dense than the Spanish style flan.

This tastes exactly like flan from a restaurant and it came out perfect. I didn't have white sugar, just raw sugar and it worked great. Also I wasn't about to make it out of condensed milk. I don't even know what that is so I was very happy to find this recipe. Yay flan!

Simple, CREAMY, and totally satisfying. WHO needs all the fancy-pants recipes that call for cream or condensed milk?!? NOT ME. This is old-school, perfect baked custard with caramel that your grandmama used to make. I was hesitant to try this, but once made, me and my co-workers were happily reminded that sometimes, KISS (Keep It Simple, Stupid) works best.
This is so good. Made Mixture of Milk and Sugar to add Egg, then used a strainer to make it silky texture and dropped Vanilla bit. Baked about 50 minutes.
Good and easy to make. I didn't make any changes and it turned out perfect ...
This was great! The only thing I changed was add a teaspoon ish of vanilla. Made it for my dad's birthday and he loved it!

Loved this! I added vanilla and used brown sugar. I used 1/4 cup of brown sugar and warmed it in the microwave and smeared it on the bottom of a single 8 by 7 Pyrex dish. I used 3 egg yolks and 2 whole eggs and 2 cups of 1 percent milk. Other than that I followed the recipe. Turned out great!! U can definitely make more than 4 servings out of this!

So Easy. So Good. 

I loved this recipe so much, it was easy and the whole family enjoyed it!

I chose this recipe because I could easily substitute the ingredients for a healthier version. I doubled the recipe and used 11 packets truvia and unsweetened vanilla almond milk instead of sugar and milk. . Very nice! Of course it would be wonderful with cream or half n half (and if you are on the "belly fat diet" I guess that would be ok) I used my own sugar free maple syrup instead of melted sugar and it was nice. Next I'll try melting truvia to see what happens. Basic flan that helps the dieter get by with sweetness and protein.

A great recipe. It is creamy, rich, and delicious, but it doesn't use many ingredients. A keeper! Just be sure not to burn the sugar, or it will taste bitter and you wont be able to wash it out of the ramekins.

This flan is smooth. I'm a new cook so I wasn't clear on carmelizing the sugar ( I added 2 tablespoons water and a drop of lemon)

The recipe is so easy and still one of the best flans I've ever eaten. Thinking I'd messed it up anyway after I added the sugar to the dishes I added a tablespoon of amaretto to two of them. All four turned out amazing. 

I will be keeping this recipe for sure. Thank you.

Turned out great. Hubby & father-in-law devored it. This was one of the few flan recipes I could find w/o sweetened condensed milk, which I didn't have and didn't want to go to the store. We had lots of half-n-half, so I used that for the "milk."

Wow this awesome flan. It is just like how my mother's taste. I used brown sugar instead and used a little bit less sugar and also strained the liquid after adding the egg so no cooked egg would be there. The taste was amazing too, not too sweet but not too dull and really smooth. Thanks!!!

Really liked it. Per the reviews and what I had in my kitchen I tweaked the recipe. Replaced: white sugar for organic brown sugar. Added: 1/2 cup non-fat greek yoghurt, 1 tbs chia seeds, and 1 tbs starbucks hot chocolate mix.
This recipe is fantastic! I add a teaspoon of vanilla and I use skim milk. So good! Makes me look like a real pro. Just one thing about the baking time, I leave it in the oven for an hour.

I give this 5 stars for the flavor and texture, although I messed up and tried to make a large flan instead of individuals. It didn't unmold too well. Next time I'll do individuals for sure, but this is as good as any flan I've ever eaten in Mexico, maybe better than most.

I followed other reviewers' suggestions and just used 4 whole eggs for this, along with half whipping cream/half milk, and a 1/2 tsp of vanilla. Superb! I am so happy to find this recipe that doesn't use canned milk. The texture and flavor was much better than another recipe I tried before. It was so smooth and creamy. Did have an eggy flavor, but that's to be expected. Thanks so much for sharing the recipe!

I also added vanilla, turned out great. Its not as rich as other recipes but still good. I strained the milk and egg mixture through a metal strainer before baking,as i would recommend with any flan, it makes it much smoother.You'd be surprised how many little egg chunkies you get out.

SMOOTH & CREAMY! This was my first time making flan and it was so easy. Perfect instructions! I used 2% milk by mistake but couldn't have had better results. I will use it next time too! Thank you Bobby Kleinveld for sharing your recipe!
This was a really good and creamy flan recipe. The directions are spot on.

I almost gave this four stars, but it just didn't have the flan flavor I was looking for. I made it because I had all of the ingredients, which wasn't the case for the other flan recipes. It was okay, but it tasted too egg-y. Not bad, and worth a try if you just really want to make flan and can't make a run to the store, but I will be trying a different recipe this time.

This is hard to mess up! I used 1 Tablespoon of cornstarch instead of 2 egg yolks...came out flippin' fantastic!! You must be a fan of this type of dessert to appreciate it. My boyfriend didn't like it, but he isn't a fan of desserts with the custard type texture. I didn't use a dishcloth underneath and it still came out perfect!

THANK YOU!!! I spent over an hour combing the internet looking for a milk-only custard/flan recipe. All the others have evaporated milk, sweetened condensed milk, and/or heavy cream -- none of which I have on hand today. My craving for my mother's baked custard has been satisfied! I substitued 2 tablespoons of Kahlua for equal amount reduced from milk, per another recipe found here on AllRecipes. YUM!
Excellent flan recipe. I always cut back the sugar in the recipes but other than that I love the egg pudding-like texture of this recipe.

This was awesome! I didn't have custard cups so I did the flans in two glass pie pans. I just did two recipes of the sugar topping and put one in each pan. Be careful not to overcook the sugar... I did in one of them and it came off with a wee bit of a burnt flavor to it. The only thing about doing big ones is that you have to be super careful taking them out of the pan. One of mine fell to pieces... but the family still devoured it :)

This will be my third time making it this year, it is AWESOME!!!! Followed the recipe given and it turns
out better and better each time!! Thanks for the recipe!!
I love flan and mine didn't turn out as well as I hoped. Next time, I will use someone else's idea of using maple syrup. I think it will be easier and will have the same taste.

I didn't like it , nothing was wrong was the texture , but the taste ..it tasted like egg with a layer of caramel ..my mom used to make flan for me using only milk , sugar and eggs but it tasted much better than this one

this came out wonderfully, i was able to use basic ingredients and 2% milk. You can get away with even less sugar. I think traditionalists miss the richness of crema and other canned goods. But for a quick easy light dessert its good. If your just making it for family you can skip the water bath and it just won't be as pretty.
I left this in for twice the time indicated and it still never set. I'm not sure what went wrong but it just didn't work for me.
I have never fixed a Flan before, this was easy to fix and tasted great. My son loved it so much that he came home at ate 2 helpings after school. This is going to be one I fix again soon.

While it may not be authentic, amazing flan, you cannot find an easier recipe! I had company over for a Mexican-themed dinner and realized I didn't have any dessert prepared. It was a risk trusting a recipe that didn't call for any of the usual dairy fats, but this worked very well and came out deliciously. 

ADD A TEASPOON OF VANILLA EXTRACT. That's my only tweak. Really, it's good for what it is!

Caveat - It's a great recipe if you don't have the ingredients to use a different recipe. If you have more time to think ahead or are thoughtful enough to keep things like condensed/evaporated milk or heavy cream around, use a different recipe.

This was an easy recipe and it looked great when I turned it out. I doubled the recipe and added orange zest, juice and a little almond extract to put a twist on it, but even so we all thought it was bland. It needs to be a bit sweeter and I possible may have had the sugar a little too dark. I might try this again.

This was so delicious! I did follow a couple of other reviews and added 1/2 tsp. vanilla, and used 1 cup of cream and 1 cup milk, since I was using 1% milk... This was such a treat and will make it again....

Light. I did use 2% milk with a little less than a full can of evaporated milk. Beat the eggs whole. Added some vanilla cognac (Navan) but didn't taste it much. Made a dulche de leche sauce from AR and used that instead of the caramelized sugar. Would make again.
This flan was super easy. came out without a hitch. and the flavor was excellent, very creamy! good presentation too.

This was a nice alternative to a traditional flan recipe. Not quite as rich and creamy, but certainly tasty! However, did make a couple of changes. First, I have a bottle of caramel syrup from a Cuban market in Florida and used that instead of cooking the sugar. The syrup is perfect for flan, and very simple. For the custard, I used one extra egg yolk and added a teaspoon of vanilla after reading reviews here. I only had 2% milk, and also added about 1/4 teaspoon nutmeg. The flan was quite good, came out of the ramekins easily and had set up nicely. I plan on keeping this recipe for whenever I want to make flan but don't have the usual ingredients on hand. Thanks!

This was AWESOME!!! I was so glad it used regular milk..... I only made two changes. I added a little bit of vanilla and I served it with that carmel sauce made for ice cream. it got all melty and was SOOOOO good : d Perfect, easy dessert for Cinco De Mayo
very good i also added a little vanilla.and i would cut the cooking time to 30 min. but extremely good!better than my father in laws and he is mexican.
I made this for my dad who is a flan fan and he loved it just as much as what he gets at the restaurant. Will def make again
I made this for my dad who is a flan fan and he loved it just as much as what he gets at the restaurant. Will def make again
Very easy to make & it tasted great! It is a lighter version of the flan my mom used to make. I added 2 tsp of vanilla extract.

Great recipe. I added some vanilla essence and served with fresh berries. The one lesson I learnt was to not stir the sugar while caramelizing - it will crystalize. Had to toss my first batch of sugar.

Perfection, a great dessert for those who don't like a whole lot of sugar in their dessert. For me the hardest part was working with the caramelized sugar. At first I decided to microwave it with just a bit of water but it burned too quickly. I ended up making the caramel on the stove and it turned out fine. Work with it quickly because the caramel hardens fast! I'll probably make it again and again because it doesn't require too many ingredients and overall the recipe is very simple

Perfection, a great dessert for those who don't like a whole lot of sugar in their dessert. For me the hardest part was working with the caramelized sugar. At first I decided to microwave it with just a bit of water but it burned too quickly. I ended up making the caramel on the stove and it turned out fine. Work with it quickly because the caramel hardens fast! I'll probably make it again and again because it doesn't require too many ingredients and overall the recipe is very simple
Nice texture. Impressive presentation for my guests! Nice that this recipe has few ingredients.
Thank you for posting a recipe that doesn't require sweetened condensed milk! This recipe was quick, easy, and really delicious!
Thank you for posting a recipe that doesn't require sweetened condensed milk! This recipe was quick, easy, and really delicious!
Easy and delicious!!!

I made it today. Perfect! Finally, an authentic recipe that starts with fresh milk and eggs! Tasty, easy, wonderful! Make sure you use whole milk and large or extra large eggs. Constant stirring at every step until you put it in the ramekins is important to keep it from burning or lumping.

I made it today. Perfect! Finally, an authentic recipe that starts with fresh milk and eggs! Tasty, easy, wonderful! Make sure you use whole milk and large or extra large eggs. Constant stirring at every step until you put it in the ramekins is important to keep it from burning or lumping.

Delicious and not too sweet. I chose this recipe because I didn't have any sweetened condensed milk on hand. I used 1/2 milk and 1/2 cream, and 3 egg yolks + 1 whole egg. I had a few bubbles in it, but it was still a hit.

I used cage free brown eggs (which have a thicker yolk) and I also used 1/2 and 1/2 rather thn mile so that may have had something to do with it but this was so creamy the texture was great! Also, I've never used a wet towel in the bottom of the pan, I didn't have any bubbles in my flan! I should add that using white sugar for the carmilzing is a must. I used organic cane juice sugar, which is silghtly brownish and more coarse than white sugar it burned badly. I will use this recipe again!

This is a very good, simple recipe. It also helped to have the step by step instructions about how to prepare the pan with water etc. I followed the recipe exactly except for adding a teaspoon of vanilla extract and it turned out perfectly.

Didn't care for it much. I've made plenty of flans before (I'm puertorican, this is a staple dessert down there) and this one is so-so. Adding hot milk to eggs is not such a great idea either. You have to be really careful or you'll end up cooking the eggs with the hot milk. Caramel is the easiest thing to do. Use the microwave!!! Add some water to the sugar in a glass container and heat it up in high for a few minutes (until you see it turn that beautiful amber color). Have done it countless times that way, believe me.
